abstract: By helping at risk children early in their lives, a long-term mentoring program pays society back many times over.
snippet: By helping at risk children early in their lives, a long-term mentoring program pays society back many times over.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

lead_paragraph: On Friday, I reported on an organization called Friends of the Children, which identifies children in kindergarten growing up in poverty and facing multiple risk factors at home and in their neighborhood - and then connects them with adult mentors for 12 years. The idea is to guarantee that these children have a consistent relationship with a caring and responsible adult whom they see at least four hours each week, from kindergarten until high school graduation.
